14907622,{'steamid': '76561198001988556', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1426397908}",english,"An offshoot of Assassin's Creed IV, it lacks the feeling of exploration, and Port-au-Prince isn't much of a city compared to Havana. At the moment though, if you don't want to pay full price of admission to Black Flag, this will satisfy your arcadey naval battle itch. After about an hour of preamble you're set loose on the (relatively small) open sea to plunder ships as you will. Naval Battle in Freedom Cry is fast paced and chaotic and a heck of a lot of fun.",1426445368,1426445368,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

14901347,"{'steamid': '76561197986511953', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1684556335}",english,"Freedom Cry is a bit of stand-alone DLC for AC4. You play as Adewale, your ship Quartermaster from AC4 turned Assassin. Who sets out on a quest of his own to liberate slaves in the Carribean.

Freedom Cry does a lot to try and be different than AC4. For starters the game is more stealth focused. For much of the game you're liberating slaves from plantations by eliminating their overseers. And the player gets rewarded with new tools, upgrades and weapons for freeing more slaves. However if the player caught they begin to murder the slaves before you can free them. This creates an incentive to play as stealthily as possible and as a result there's significantly less of a combat focus. This was clearly intentional and you tend to only use your blowgun and hidden blades.

As a result Freedom Cry feels significantly more like a stealth action game than any of the previous Assassin Creed games. And it's to it's credit. The only real gripes I have with it are the story is a bit lacking compared to AC4 and it doesn't take you that long to complete. It is priced pretty reasonably though and it's a blast to try and complete 100%.
I highly recommend Freedom Cry. It complements AC4 nicely, and its more focused stealth gameplay is a welcome change.",1426422994,1426426584,True,39,4,0.791160166263580322,0,True,False,False,False,,,

14638704,"{'steamid': '76561198082887288', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1418967540}",english,"Ok so i really like Assasins Creed. In fact I like it so much that I'm probbably still going to get unity, but the thing that makes the games great is that they are big. If you played and love black flag and you want more, then I'd say that you should play black flag more or get rouge when it comes out. This game is very small, very very small, you're in a world of wide open seas and enjoying sailing and pirating and oh look at that, the map ended, time to sail back and fourth I guess. I like the machete and the blunderbuss except I keep killing people i don't want to with the bluderbuss. The ship isn't that great and you can't upgrade it that much in fact i don't even remember the name. The biggest response the game got from me was when I found my Jackdaw at the bottom of the sea, it was absolutely heart breaking, then I just wanted to play black flag.",1424810227,1424810227,False,3,0,0.466424673795700073,0,True,False,False,False,,,

14426062,"{'steamid': '76561198054495945', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1472684804}",english,"i really liked the idea of it being stand alone DLC, and bought it durring the winter sale for i think $3.50 or so. it took me a while to get around to playing it tho and once i did my fear was confirmed that there was no tutorial of any kind. i hadent played any assasins creed games since the first one so jumping right in is very confusing, but i have no one to blame but myself for that. i just wanted to warn other people who were thinking of getting this for thier first assasins creed, you are already expected to know how to play.

aside from that as i bumble through, its a very pretty game/dlc, and i like playing as Adewale. so far so good, would recomend if you have played alot of assassins creed, recomend getting the full game if you havent tho.",1423613492,1423613492,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

14201856,"{'steamid': '76561198032669768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1071, 'last_played': 1673069714}",english,"Bought it on sale for like 3 or 4 bucks.

Adewale is easily one of the most bad@ss protagonists in the entire AC series. I especially love the gruesome killmoves he can pull off. The Blunderbuss and Machete are great weapons too and I love their designs, but nothing beats hanging slavers on tree branches.
The story is really short (9 missions in all) but there's more than enough freeroam pirating and assassinating to go around. The final mission in particular has a very satisfying finish.
Also, freeing virtual slaves makes me feel like a good person, so that's a plus too.
The graphics are stunning but this means the game requires a high end rig to play with decent performance.
If you can get this game on sale, it's very much worth it. I've had a lot of fun with it and certainly got my money's worth.",1422411320,1422411369,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

14160246,{'steamid': '76561198005069663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1435493603}",english,"â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† - ""Worth your time, give it a bash""
PROS:
- For what is a 4 hour long piece of DLC, it has fun additional content which bulks it out so you can get your monies worth
- Makes use of Black Flags graphics and features which is some of the best of the Creed franchise
- Mixed missions but overall a more gung ho style of action, the machetes are great and more battle ships action
- Adewale is a awesome character and his story is straight forward and interesting
- The game doesnt force you into anything you dont want to do or approach missions a certain type of way
CONS:
- Assassins Creed gameplay is always hit or miss for me, one action sequence can make you feel like a world beater but the next you'll be shouting at the screen cause he wouldnt counter.
- Again with gameplay it can sometimes feel clunky and those chase scenes potentially have immersion breakers when he starts running up that god damn door or tree for no reason.
VERDICT?

Where assasssins creed games begin to fall flat as the story gets boring and missions tedious, Freedom Cry is just right and rather than feeling like a chore, you actually wish for more.",1422186585,1450838535,True,139,7,0.88391190767288208,3,True,False,False,False,,,

14150277,"{'steamid': '76561197992926367', 'num_games_owned': 1633, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1422132217}",english,"Assassins Creed Freedom Cry review.

As an avivid assassins creed series fan, having completed all to a 95%+ completetion rate as well as following the series before it started. i quite liked this spin off, being the Black ex-slave to free your brothers felt very rewarding.
+ Graphics as always with AC games
+ Storyline - amazing story line
+ Voice acting - very realistic sounds
+ slave idea is so unique and amazing! really enjoyed it.
- buggy as hell like previous AC's. they always release them way too soon!

- controls, dislike how ""free"" running isn't very free and seems to always go in the wrong direction you want it to. the character can jump 4 feet up and grab a tiny crack but not pull run up a wall with bars you can easily hold on to. this has happened since the free running changed from ""A"" (on xbox controllers) to ""RT"" it seems to be terrible now.
- story length was pathetic with this one. 3 hours it took me to get 93% completion. i realised after 2 missions i was 42% through so tried to take my time but there wasn't many side quests.
Overall graphics 8.5/10
gameplay 6.5/10
story 8/10
Replability? No unfortunatly, its not long enough to enjoy again.",1422132890,1422132890,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

13953015,"{'steamid': '76561198076634375', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1421038130}",english,"Definitely a fun game, Adewale is a much more brutal, self conflicted character than Edward Kenway and its interesting seeing the way that affects Adewale's weapon choice, fighting style and overall decision making. Definitely fun for a DLC, the story is gripping too, the portrayal of the horrors of slavery feel real, and it makes you want to see the story through to its end. 13614495,"{'steamid': '76561197960554264', 'num_games_owned': 918, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1419610928}",english,"While I cannot atest to the quality of Assassin's Creed IV, III was an utter mess. Glitchy, buggy, time-wasting and otherwise lost in the sea of AAA checkpoints just to make a sale; Connor deserved a much better game surrounding his wonderfully built world.

This seemed to be the trend with a lot of Ubisoft titles as of late. Stuff the world full of as much nonsense as you can and hope the players get distracted to ignore the flaws. It didn't work in the case of Assassin's Creed III and I have no idea how much superfluous extras there are in IV. With this standalone campaign, though, Ubisoft have finally nailed a perfect balance of missions and pacing.

No longer do you need to trek through mindless set ups and investigations to get to the good stuff. Freedom Cry almost sticks to action 100% of the time, but you do get some small diversions to break up the monotony. Forcing side missions on the player isn't that nice, but the missions are given some extra weight due to the setting and narrative.

As for the plotline, I can't say that I was impressed. I love the idea of a former slave joining the creed and exacting vengeance, but I think IV had more setup for main character, Adewale, that is missing from this. Even the beginning of the game seems like it was already underway before my intervention.

The game also does succumb to being a bit scripted. One of the later missions on a sinking ship would have been exhilerating if there were some actual danger involved. Instead, you simply can wait around until the game tells you to leave and be done with it. Smoke and mirrors was the name of the game with III and I'm sad to see it still being utilized here.

There are also the occassional problems with pathfinding while running and combat getting lost with the camera. I often couldn't tell what I was doing or had a hard time stopping myself from performing one action and ended up failing missions. It can be aggravating when you fail due to no fault of your own, but the extremely generous checkpoints make nearly every mistake moot.

The game is also exceptionally easy. I messed up in a few parts with naval battles, but that was mostly because of my lack of experience with them (I know IV is based around naval encounters). The ship mechanics are vastly improved from III and are actually quite enjoyable. I wouldn't mind getting into more of them.

So overall, Freedom Cry is a nice little diversion from the normal Assassin's Creed experience. It's short length makes it great to plow through in one sitting. It's also a lot more consistent in quality and mission structure than III could ever hope to be.

While it may feel a little undercooked, it still rings true as a beacon of fresh air within this franchise. Hopefully Ubisoft realizes that jamming your game with extraneous missions isn't the best way to garner value for your title.

13581189,"{'steamid': '76561198006374681', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1419474214}",english,"I was waiting for AC: Unity, but since it is bug-laden, this came highly recommended by the community. Although short, I enjoyed playing through the story. One of the better AC games after the Ezio trilogy. I wished Adewale (main character) could keep more weapons but his main is only a machete. There are times when you can either play stealthily or mow anyone down (although with a penalty) so there is some variation in play styles.
To those who also enjoy the ship portion of AC 3 and AC4, this game comes with a significant portion of that but it's not really that important. I enjoyed harpooning whales and sharks (mini-game).

13481608,"{'steamid': '76561198134182594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1448330827}",english,"Assassin's Creed can have a lot of crap DLC spin off games. But this one is actually decent, Unlike the DLC's on Assassin's Creed III, This game feels more like it's own game compared to other DLC's. I bought this recently on the Winter sale and for the 3 dollars i spent on Freedom Cry was clearly worth it. It's a short black flag but as a different character dealing with the emotional ties of slavery. This game is much mroe emotional and makes the story a lot more interesting than Edward Kenway's story. Positives: exact same tight and well made controls like Black Flag, A much more interesting Story, New interesting characters, fun side quests (but can get repetitive) great value on steam for it's content. for a 9-3 dollar price range it's so worth it. Cons: Short, Uninteresting roaming, Open world is the smallest in the series and can feel dull at times, few more glitches than Black Flag, Critic: 7/10 Personal: 8/10 FOR A DLC 8,5/10",1419109323,1419109323,True,7,0,0.505313396453857422,0,True,False,False,False,,,

13364443,"{'steamid': '76561198088033314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1418480769}",english,"[h1][b]Cry for more[/b][/h1]
[h1][b]Full Review at [url=http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=126]GameDragons.Net[/url][/b][/h1]
[b]Presentation[/b]

Freedom Cry tells the story of Black Flag's AdÃ©walÃ©, twenty years after the story of Edward Kenway, following AdÃ©walÃ© in his journey through the West Indies Sea, where he ends up shipwrecked on the coast of Haiti. Making his way into Port-au-Prince he meets up with Bastienne JosÃ¨phe, the proprietor of a local brothel and a sympathiser to the Maroons, a faction of freedom fighters made up of liberated slaves. Soon afterwards AdÃ©walÃ© gets caught up in the events and ends up teaming with the Maroons to free slaves from around the West Indies Sea.

As emotional and personal the story is, its length demolishes almost everything the plot wants to uncover, as most missions will be over before you realize it, leaving details aside and focusing only on the main objectives, therefore taking away from the emotional impact the story could've had if we were presented with some background on the slaves and their masters which AdÃ©walÃ© is supposed to fight blindly. AdÃ©walÃ©'s relationship with Bastienne JosÃ¨phe is one of the few things that stands out strong throughout the six hour adventure, as you will find out more about her intentions from one visit to the next one, and by the end of the story form a bond with her that you could only wish would continue for a few more hours.
[b]Gameplay[/b]

Being an extension to Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, Freedom Cry plays exactly the same, with a few interesting things added for the best, and a lot of amazing features present in the original game removed for the worst. This is still an open world game, so you can use your ship to travel from one location to another just like you did in Black Flag, but not only is the game limited to the West Indies Sea which is a pretty small portion of the Caribbean, but at the same time that portion feels empty in a way that Black Flag never did, even with its enormous map.

There are only three main islands where the main plot will take you and maybe five more where you can find a chest or a secret, but for the most part the seas feel empty, and even in those main islands aside from the objective where the mission takes you and the slave liberation missions there is nothing else to do, something that feels weird to begin with for an Assassin's Creed game. On the bright side, the Blunderbuss and AdÃ©walÃ©'s machete are some great new tools to play around with, at least in the main missions since that's the only occasion you'll get to use them properly.
[b]Graphics[/b]

Freedom Cry was built as an extension to Black Flag, so it uses the same engine and environment, which is only for the best since the original game was a beauty with vast seas, populated lands and unforgiving fleets. In this title, the seas are still there in all their beauty and so are the ships cruising them, but the difference comes when you set sail for land and realize there is nothing else to see there; unlike Black Flag, Freedom Cry has only a few islands and even those look similar, as no matter which one you set foot on next, you'll still be greeted by the same slave plantation or empty beach.
[b]Audio[/b]

With such great audio design and quality in Black Flag, it was impossible to screw it up this time, since most of it is reused in here, which isn't much of a problem since all the effects feel authentic in AdÃ©walÃ©'s story as well. There are a couple new tunes created for Freedom Cry exclusively and those find their spot in AdÃ©walÃ©'s story flawlessly, and thanks to some great voice acting performed by Tristan D. Lalla, AdÃ©walÃ©'s character feels even more authentic than it did before in Black Flag throughout Kenway's story.
[b]Extras[/b]

Even though this can be purchased as a standalone experience, it is obviously just an extension to Black Flag, but even so playing an Assassin's Creed game where you can barely squeeze six hours of playtime if you're taking your time with the story, completing all the slave liberation missions and looking around for the few islands that hide a chest feels weird since Assassin's Creed was always about exploration and the things you can do on the side, things that are almost non-existent in Freedom Cry.
[b]Verdict[/b]

Freedom Cry wanted to tell a more personal story than the original Black Flag, but unfortunately the limited length of the story, as well as the empty environment in which it takes place makes it fall flawed as important and emotional events will be over before realizing it and for most parts without any explanation or background on AdÃ©walÃ©'s intentions.

13202999,{'steamid': '76561197960550055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1448842249}",english,"[h1]TLDR [/h1] A sloppy and underwhelming DLC product that does a disservice to both it's subject matter and original game. Buy the base game, Assassins Creed 4: Black Flag, or Assassins Creed: Rogue.
[h1]Tone Deaf [/h1]

The narrative feels rushed and unfocused, beginning and ending rather abruptly. It starts with your classic AC MacGuffin, then promptly forgets about it; Then touches on themes of slavery but begins to quickly move them to the backround, instead focusing too much of it's narrative on a cartographer mapping the Caribbean that happens to be in Port au Prince (The primary setting of this DLC.) This leads to far too many tail/eavesdrop missions, moreso some of the worst, most frustrating examples in any of the AC games to date. It relies too much on tightly scripted sequences that limit your mobility and/or abilities and mistakes tedium for engagement too often. The main story missions can be completed in under 4 hours.

The freeing of slaves is relegated mostly to narrative-devoid side activities, tied to unlocking upgraded weapons and other optional items, cheapening the poignancy to the point of repetitively farming a statistic. The repetition is not helped by the rapid respawn of prisoners; I could return to the same spot within two minutes to find new caged prisoners, new guards taking the exact same routes, the corpses of their predecessors still laying about.
[h1]Landlubber [/h1]

The game is really at it's best when you are raiding plantations. You free the slaves of the plantation by killing guards. It's just nice having that chance to take it on in your own way, with your full set of skills and the space to use them instead of limiting them like a majority of the main missions. It's always the same objective, Kill 20 guards, and it feels like a wasted opportunity; It could have used more variety to keep it fresh, and without narrative it only serves as a distraction from the underwhelming storyline.

Sailing feels like an afterthought, with a very small map and only a handful of locations to explore, with many of those being little more than beaches with a chest or two on them. After all the sea shanties of AC4, it is very noticeable that Adewale's ship crew is generally silent; it would have been nice if there were a couple of new, theme appropriate songs for them to sing, or just a few of the old ones. There are no treasure maps to find, no forts to destroy, no side assassinations to undertake. Hunting and whaling are pointless as there's nothing to craft. I didn't even notice there were ship upgrades until the second playthrough, the ship's upgraded enough out of the gate to deal with the few ship-to-ship fights. It's also painfully obvious you're always sailing the Jackdaw, the recycled ship model from the main game (AC4 Black Flag.) The ship you're sailing and sinks out of the gate is identical, and then the next one you steal is EXACTLY THE SAME, right down to the decorations, even the three skulls hanging over captains quarters entrance.

The new items border on impractical: The blunderbuss is a shrapnel-spread shotgun that's just as likely to kill the slaves you're trying to free or your crew as you board other ships; The noise-making firecrackers can only be dropped right in front of you and the noise doesn't seem to have much distance. The Machete is a sword, just like any other AC game, albeit with some pretty sweet, brutal animations. The animations are sort of aesthetically flawed since they go on a little long in combos and tend to get cut off as you parry other enemies in groups.
[h1]Drunken Sailor [/h1]

As with other recent series entries, this one suffers from an inconsistent frame rate and animation/scripting bugs that mar it's presentation. I watched a hunter's ship sail up the side of an islands rocky peak and into the air before flipping back into the water. I was caught during tailing/eavesdrop missions because sometimes the target would get caught on something/someone and would do a quick spin on the spot, seeing in all directions at once for a second. Sometimes freeing slaves would spawn guards out of thin air (Maybe not a bug but it happened a lot, it was tedious and annoying.) The frame rate plummets noticeably at seemingly random intervals and occasionally assets will materialise in front of Adewale as he runs through the streets.
[h1]A Ship Without An Anchor [/h1]

Adewale is a potentially interesting and charismatic character and I was hoping to get to know him a bit better, as well as explore a very dark aspect of colonialism that was largely glossed over in AC 3 and 4. Freedom Cry does little to add much dimension to it's protagonist, seems uncomfortable confronting the issues of it's own subject matter, and it's disappointing it failed to approach it with compelling narrative or engaging gameplay.",1417552981,1550163059,False,11,0,0.434134095907211304,0,True,False,False,False,,,

12853078,"{'steamid': '76561198059607035', 'num_games_owned': 2173, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1415490834}",spanish,"[h1]  Â¿Una expansiÃ³n de AC IV: Blackflag necesaria?   	 [/h1]

En AssassÃ­n's Creed: Freedom Cry seremos AdÃ©walÃ©, un esclavo que huyÃ³ de su miseria para hacerse independiente y poder lograr la independencia de los esclavos que eran de raza negra, recordemos que fue Edward Kenway el que lo ayudÃ³ a liberarse, es casi necesario jugar AC IV para poder entender mejor a AdÃ©walÃ©, es decir, lo que fue, lo que es y lo que serÃ¡.

El juego es muy similar a AC IV, por no decir que igual, tiene el mismo motor grÃ¡fico, jugabilidad, las misiones si bien no son las mismas, son similares. Tiene algunos cambios, sobretodo en armas, agregan un par mÃ¡s, asÃ­ como un dardo nuevo, como sea, no es realmente una gran innovaciÃ³n y si acabaste AC IV forzosamente, entonces tal vez no querrÃ¡s jugar este juego.

La historia no es muy atrapante, basicamente es lograr la independencia de tu raza, para eso debes empezar poco a poco, liberando esclavos, luego grupos mayores, asÃ­ como destruir barcos... Lo que realmente me parece que vale la pena este juego es el final, si bien durante todo el juego vemos a esclavos en jaulas o llevados por la fuerza, es en el climax donde AdÃ©walÃ© intenta salvar mÃ¡s esclavos,  en esa misiÃ³n vemos a esclavos sufrir mucho, algunos murieron por hambre, otros incinerados, pero todos piden misericordia, incluso cuando escapas logras ver cadaveres de inocentes por todas partes.

Si eres fan de AssassÃ­n Creed entonces deberÃ­as probar este juego, ya que nos ofrece algo muy similar a AC IV, solamente que con otro personaje como principal, si no es lo tuyo los AC entonces tal vez deberÃ­as dejarlo pasar. En general me parece que cumple y que vale la pena probarlo.

12592387,"{'steamid': '76561198080761848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1452627568}",english,"wow, i must say  that i really enjoy this game so far, unlike other assasin creed titles that i allways quit playing them after short time playing, in this game you don't need rise your hero from birth and change his diapers, you know what i mean...  here you start right in the middle of action, on a fascinating boat battle, the rest off the game meanwhile is also fun cause you fight for good things like free slaves and all of that and it's gives you a really good feeling, the graphics is goregeus and it's considerably cheap (at least when i bought it on sale)...recomended.

12589326,"{'steamid': '76561198106475330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1413848661}",english,"Eh, yuck.",1413849215,1413849215,False,3,1,0.35279497504234314,0,False,False,False,False,,,

12585376,"{'steamid': '76561198076587335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1600615474}",english,"I bought AC:FC as solo game after finishing Black Flag. Well, this really should remain only as DLC. A few hours more of sidestory of AdÃ©walÃ© liberating his black brothers from slavery. A few just eavesdropping or following missions, where you could easily get punished when leaving stealth. Don't like the way the game pushes you to be stealth, you just have no option.

Felt more free when playing older AC's beforce AC3 came. I love stealth, but don't like the way FreedomCry literally pushes you into the corner during story missions and punishes you by failing mission without any possibility to run away or fight etc.

Game itself has same assets, animations and whole core are from Black Flag, so beside of main story you can again sail the beatiful sea on a few isles and liberat slaves from slaveships or from plantations, which are infinitely occupied againg some time after you liberate them. Hunting/fishing and revealing a few unknown locations is here too.
Not bad, but not so good, expected more or a bit richier story of AdwÃ©walÃ©. Nice setting and characters, i could imagine whole game based on slavery theme.

Anyway i loved different approach when liberating plantations during day and during night. Most of time there is a static daytime (i loved dynamic daytime in AC2/Bhd/Rvs), but you can easily change daytime between day and night ... same was as in FarCry2 ;).
If you're AC fan as probably i am ;) you can give it try, but don't expect too much.",1413825494,1413825494,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

12484666,"{'steamid': '76561198055869214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1413052989}",english,One of my favorite assasin creed games. 12479707,"{'steamid': '76561198063955453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1413224126}",english,"Now, as a long term Assassin's Creed fan I was super god damn excited to play this game when I saw it on sale. However, when I finished it a day or so later, I felt a little disappointed.

This game overall feels more like a couple of long DLC missions in the main game than a stand alone game. It's entertaining enough if you liked Black Flag, because this is basically the same, but on a much smaller, less interesting scale. It feels like you're just playing as a reskinned Edward, as the idle animations are the exact same. You can hunt certain animals, but there's no purpose, because you can't craft or make more outfits. Like in Black Flag, you can plunder other ships, but the rewards are so badly scaled to the prices of the few upgrades, that you're basically decked out after you've pulverized four ships. Freedom Cry feels like someone cut a tiny square out of the bayeux tapestry. It's aesthetically pleasing in itself, but it's lacking a whole hell of a lot of context.

I personally don't feel like Freedom Cry's got enough content or weight to be its own game. I played it, I completed it, it was okay while it lasted, but in a critical light, this really isn't that big of a deal. I would't recommend buying this unless it's on sale.",1413225031,1413225089,False,23,3,0.48898845911026001,1,True,False,False,False,,,

12471644,"{'steamid': '76561198042405745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1416197180}",english,"Seems like it will be a good game.  But this is the first I have played any of the Assassin games, there is no tutorial mode to teach you how to fight move, climb drive a boat, shoot a cannon, clime a tree jump.  Nothing, you just die and reload and try again.  I am guessing you had to start from a previous/older version of the Assassin series to figure this out.  Kind of frustrating.  Let me know if one of the other games have a build up/training mode to help you learn the ins and outs of moving and combat?  Thanks.

I went out and bought a gamepad to see if that would help play this game.  Nope.  this game sucks on PC, not really configurable.  I can't seem to custumize it any usful way.  I think there is too much automatic assumptions made based on my movement and I can't control anything very well.  The start of the game on the ship, I seem to be able to do that with Keyboard and Mouse better then with the gamepad, but fighting and basic movement is completely skewed and there is no tutorial on playing.  There is a few tips that pop up durring a battle, I trying not to die, fighing clicking random buttons and trying to read directions at the same time...  WTF!!  Big flaw in the design there.

Gamepad X, Y configs are screwed too, I can't reverse one with out reversing both, so it modifies left and right if I modify up and down.  ??   ARG!  This seems like it would be a fun game, but I think I might shoot myself if I try to play it anymore.",1413159497,1416197748,False,1,1,0.424929201602935791,0,True,False,False,False,,,

12439024,"{'steamid': '76561198028441242', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 178, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1412967002}",english,"Freedom Cry is the main DLC content for Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag and follows the efforts of Adewale, Edward Kenway's former quartermaster and now an Assassin, to aid the Maroon slaves rebellion around the town of Port'au'Prince.

Compared to the main game, Freedom Cry's main novelity as a DLC are the liberation side quest, which involves completing random events around the map in order to free slaves and obtain more rebels on the protagonist's side. Clearing these events becomes mandatory later on due to some main missions being unlocked only after a certain quota of slaves has been achieved. There are also some plantations the player can raid to further boost the rebels rank.

Aside from these events, Freedom Cry doesn't offer much new content or mechanics, fancing itself as just a smaller version of Black Flag which can be cleared in under four hours. It's also worth mentioning that the naval features are barely used in the DLC at all, due to the far smaller overall map and the main missions taking place mainly in Port'au'Prince.

What makes Freedom Cry worth a shot from any player from the Assassin's Creed series is the compelling story, which sets it quite apart from Edward's adventure and manages to be both engaging and rather touching",1412969931,1468752101,True,14,0,0.640748322010040283,0,False,False,False,False,,,

12421064,"{'steamid': '76561198052263435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1412849459}",english,"If you are Porting a game from being a DLC to being a stand alone means you need to add contect for those players who bought it as stand alone. They failed at this. Instructions flash up on your screen super fast and if you miss them you have to dig deep into the menue to see them again, so I spent a LOT of time jumping back and forward from the menue.

Then theres no dialog, no music and no story contect for me at the beging. I don't know who i'm playing or why i'm ment to care and there's little make me want to find out. Then the second part of the opening level is an underwater scene. Underwater levels are almost universally hated in Video games, but Since Black Flag was so loved I figured they must have sorted this underwater shit out (it is a game set at sea after all), NOPE.

Breath bars, no weapons, marauding sharks and clumsy controls, all while i'm still learning how the game operates! I stopped there, and that's as far as I plan to take my Pirate adventures.",1412849885,1412849885,False,6,0,0.48336416482925415,1,True,False,False,False,,,

12213331,"{'steamid': '76561198071960199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1435989454}",english,"This game is an absolute blast to play, provided you don't want to actually play the game and you're content to simply stare at the beautiful graphics motionless. When I say this game runs about as well as my 81 year old grandma who just had her hip replaced, I feel like I'm being generous. The number of times I've died due to unresponsive controls from the [i]single digit[/i] frame rate have me feeling like I could cut off my big toe from frustration. Taking a ship can be stressful enough simply because of the frustratingly poor camera controls and the series' signature crappy combat, but playing this in slide show mode can make it simply impossible. It isn't that I have the settings too high or that my rig is too old, I have two 4 gb gtx 760s going with a i7-3770k, far beyond the recommended settings, with the graphics settings on low, and still there is no noticeable improvement with the frame rate. I have to say that this is one time it's simply better to play the game on a console, unless you're okay with shit optimization and unresponsive controls. Then the game is fantastic, simply a must buy. Such a disappointment because this game could be so incredibly fun, but even moving your character around get incredibly jittery frame rates (I feel like I'm playing a ps3 instead of a $1600 gaming rig that handles far more intensive games with ease).

11891168,"{'steamid': '76561198061919148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1448138713}",french,.20/20,1409182769,1409182769,True,2,0,0.48207169771194458,0,True,False,False,False,,,

11888556,"{'steamid': '76561198007104822', 'num_games_owned': 783, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1409154498}",english,"Assassin's Creed: Freedom Cry.
While not throwing stealth away completely, this game trades up stealth for some head on action sequences.
You play as Adewale, 15 years after the events of Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.
Older, wiser and now a fully trained assassin. He even gets his own murder hood.

Much of the in game assets were from ACIV:BF so the graphics are more or less the same. Gameplay wise as well, but again more action than stealth really. And his attack animations, though not as fluid or graceful as i expected assassins would be, he has a sort of brutal flair that really defines him as an assassin. Not just Edward Kenway reskinned to be Adewale.
Weapons in Freedom Cry are different as they got rid of swords and daggers. You get machetes for Adewale instead. (This does not prevent you from picking up and using a sword from a slain enemy.)
No flintlock pistols, just a blunderbuss for you, Ade.
You still have your own pair of Hidden Blades of course.

The whole campaign itself is short and sweet. It left me wanting more from it, more of what happens to Adewale, more of what becomes of the liberated slaves and their resistance and more of what happened to the Assassins after Black Flag.
For a DLC turned standalone game, it has a lot more content than one would expect.
Honestly i thought it was just gonna be a bunch of uninspired self contained missions, but this totally blew me away.
I dare say Adewale was more fun to play with than Connor. But of course, that is my opinion.

Get it on sale if you feel that $15 is still too much. Get it however you can as it is a very good game and you won't really regret playing it.",1409165848,1409165956,True,395,4,0.942232728004455566,7,False,False,False,False,,,

11877091,"{'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4499, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1409080375}",english,"+ Plenty of content
+ Same pretty graphics as in Black Flag (obviously)
+ Feels more action oriented (instead of stealthy), and because of it feels sort of fresh
- More glitches and bugs
- Repetitive missions with little variety
- Story not so interesting

11868109,"{'steamid': '76561198000735651', 'num_games_owned': 741, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1509075441}",english,"It took me 12.8 hours to finish a 3 hour gameâ€¦ BECAUSE IT WAS AMAZING! The story in Assassinâ€™s Creed Freedom Cry was SOOO MUCH MORE EMOTIONAL than it was in Assassinâ€™s Creed IV Black Flag! I absolutely love this game! UGH! SO GOOD! I bought this game before Black Flag as a stand alone expansion but once I finish Black Flag today, I decided to finish it and it was SOOO GOOD! I recommend it especially if you have only so little to spend on games :P It is super cheap",1409021798,1409021798,True,44,0,0.675661087036132813,0,True,False,False,False,,,

11838325,"{'steamid': '76561197971042239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 969, 'last_played': 1409611028}",english,"I was compelled to try 'Assassin's Creed Freedom Cry' after learning that slavery is the primary theme of the game. It is a game full of potential -- beautiful graphics, excellent voice acting, and a seldomly explored subject matter tied together with a commercially proven gaming formula. Yet, while 'Freedom Cry' was not horrible, it was not stellar or impressive as it should be. What we got is a game with a partially developed character, about whom I actually want to learn more, in a half-baked story that felt like 'Assassin's Creed' Lite.

It was innovative to play as a slave-turned-Assassin, who despite having gifts and talents bestowed upon him by the Brotherhood, still needed to be weary of slave jailers because of the colour of his skin. This was enough to change the usual pace of an 'Assassin's Creed' game, and I quite enjoyed that. Not needing to deal with modern day Abstergo/Animus story elements was also very welcomed, but it was odd to see the concept of synchronicity being left in the game. The modern day story elements in 'Assassin's Creed' had always felt like Ubisoft lacked confidence in a loosely historical third-person stealth action game. 'Freedom Cry' would have been the perfect opportunity for the franchise to distant itself from this extraneous story element, but that chance was unfortunately wasted.

My biggest complaint about 'Freedom Cry', is the naval combat. As someone who had not played 'Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag', I found the learning curve for naval warfare to be steep. There wasn't much of a tutorial and it took much trial and error for me to fully understand the basic mechanics. Plus, there was one mission that would have been difficulty to complete if I had not fully upgraded my ship through constant pirating. Such level grinding has no place in a game like 'Freedom Cry' as it slowed the entire game down. That and the repetitiveness and general lack of mission variety made the game rather tedious at times. Seriously, how many eavesdropping missions did 'Freedom Cry' really need for a nine-mission game?

The theme of slavery is both a shining factor and a major weakness of 'Freedom Cry'. I got much satisfaction freeing slaves in the game, but when the number of slaves I freed became the currency of weapon upgrades eligibility, I became frustrated. Shouldn't I be freeing slaves because it is the right thing to do and because it is the main character's motivation, not because of a weapon upgrade? Plus, why would black merchants, who knew I free slaves, only sell me weapons if I meet a quota? This game mechanic, while thematically important, was not very well thought out and well implemented.

For those who have played 'Black Flag', 'Freedom Cry' may appeal to you, but for those who haven't, your time may be better spent on other games than this somewhat mediocre entry to the 'Assassin's Creed' franchise.",1408828492,1409612455,False,109,3,0.600208163261413574,5,False,False,False,False,,,

So benissimo che Ã¨ un' espansione, ma Ã¨ anche stand alone, quindi almeno 6 ore dovrebbe durare...
Le missioni secondarie, sono sempre uguali e mancano di originalitÃ , ovvero:
A: Libera gli schiavi dalle piantagioni dove sono rinchiusi
B: Assalta le navi dove sono tenuti prigionieri gli schiavi
C: Trova tesori nascosti
D: Visita relitti sottomarini
E molte altre cose giÃ  presenti in Assassin' s creed 4 Black Flag...

Da fan della saga posso dire che Ã¨ il peggior capitolo/espansione della saga di Assassin's creed... Senza contare che il prezzo Ã¨ eccessivo in una maniera vergognosa, cazzo 15 euro che volano via...

11704851,"{'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1408041892}",english,"The final Assassins Creed game of the marathon and the series. Freedom Cry is actually a standalone game of Blackflag era. Although I wasn't a huge fan of Blackflag, this one did end up with me wanting more at the end.

The main character, AdewalÃ©, who also played a part in Blackflag is one of the most bad-ass characters I've played, not just in Assassin's Creed, but gaming as a whole. The is built like a tank, and won't take any crap from anybody. Proper bad ass.

The story is very DLC style length, and leaves you wanting more after you complete the main mission. There is still plenty of side quests, challenges and hidden treasures to find once you finish it, so for a standalone game, the quantity of gameplay is actually rather impressive.
Graphics wise, very impressive. Built on the same engine as Blackflag, you will not find your self disappointed at the visual side of this title.

I would highly recommend this game. If you are unsure about purchasing Blackflag, this is probably your best starting point as the gameplay is exactly the same, almost like a long demo. As a stand alone as well, this is a very well put together game that you will certainly get a lot of enjoyment out of.
More reviews at - http://completingthebacklog.blogspot.co.uk/

11375809,"{'steamid': '76561198084944727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1412205962}",english,"Great game. In my opinion Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag was one of the best, if not the best game of the series. It felt really good to be able to play something related to it just a little bit more. Playing as Adewale was really interesting since he was an important character to the original story. Also, the side quests (related to saving slaves) were very entertaining as there were different ways to do it.
I only wish the game was longer. Each mission you complete represents 8% of it more or less. So there were something around 10 main missions.
Although there could have been more to it, it's still a pretty good game which you must buy if you're a Assassin's Creed fan.",1406122434,1406122434,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

11192210,"{'steamid': '76561197995669497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1408017805}",english,"The game is a mixed bag, it gives you 4-6 hours of simple fun with a few long story missions but also makes things way to simple/basic. Your given the task of freeing and recruiting slaves, but sadly never given the chance to manage them. All you get rewarded with is your hideout slightly changing and a few upgrades to your weapons.

The game really shines with the navy combat, over the few hours you will go from what feels like a small fishing boat to a battleship, with small whaling mini games and a few small beaches to explore.
I think its a fantastic buy for those who want a short game and dont need to invest too much time into a complex game.",1405129074,1405129126,True,2,0,0.530547857284545898,0,True,False,False,False,,,

10924442,"{'steamid': '76561198004651403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1403687041}",english,"I wouldn't say this is one of the better Assassin's Creed games I've played.  The storyline was a bit iffy and not much happened.  I wasn't really sure what was happening with that Templar package.  This game did not really make an impact on the series, being that the storyline was so short and too simple.  I spent 6 hours in the game and that was me taking my time.  There was a lack of actual Assassins at work other than our protagonist.  Although slavery itself is historically accurate, not much of what Adewale did seemed to be on the history timeline.  I don't see any memorable characters in this game that were worth interacting with or assassinating.  The game should cost no more than $5 with the amount of content that they gave.",1404003891,1404003891,False,13,1,0.517353236675262451,0,True,False,False,False,,,

10883663,"{'steamid': '76561198090468054', 'num_games_owned': 3608, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1403902577}",italian,"Questo gioco Ã¨ un piccolo siparietto ottimamente realizzato sul periodo storico e sul luogo che vuol rappresentare. Tutto viene delinato con toni a tratti retorici e a tratti non, esattamente come il gioco di cui era in origine dlc, rendendo alla fine una sensazione di ""veritÃ "" veramente immersiva. In questo la saga di AC ha fatto passi da gigante. Da notare la spettacolare colonna sonora, remix orchestrato di temi popolari haitiani. Non ci sono notevoli innovazioni di gameplay rispetto agli altri capitoli della saga: il machete e la spingarda sono piÃ¹ revisioni estetiche che vertono su un senso di maggiore brutalitÃ . La trama per essere cosÃ¬ breve ha dei momenti salienti di grande tensione, come la nave di schiavi che affonda e il finale, anch'esso rapido ma molto  profondo nelle gestualitÃ  e d'atmosfera.

Unica pecca Ã¨ la davvero pessima ottimizzazione per pc, che mi ha costretto a giocare a una risoluzione abbastanza bassa per avere un'esperienza fluida (e su questo pc girano giochi coevi al massimo!). Per il resto, acquisto consigliatissimo per i fan e non della saga.",1403901761,1403901761,True,0,0,0,0,True,False,False,False,,,

10345288,{'steamid': '76561198097251562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1418467387}",english,"Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag: Freedom Cry Standalone game review:

In this Assassin's Creed game you are Adewale, a big black dude with a machete and a blunderbuss (Big shotgunny thing). You were formerly a slave, working on a plantation until pirates raided it. Although Adewale was previously the legendary Edward Kenway's Quartermaster, Adewale found that he wanted to save slaves, rather than be a pirate. In this game, you follow him across the Carribean, as he liberates slaves and recruits maroons.

The quality of the game is FANTASTIC! A new feature for the AC series (which was also introduced in Black Flag) is sailing across open world areas, rather than only whilst on missions (in Assassin's Creed 3). Sailing is incredibly simple as all you do is press the forward key, maybe move left and right, etc. A feature of the game (which personally had me excited) was the ability to board other enemy vessels. Boarding too is simple. All you do is press the S key (or whatever you have set stop to) whilst alongside another almost destroyed vessel, and it will automatically cause your ship to dock alongside. Your crew too will react, throwing Grappling hooks to draw your vessels nearer to each other.Your crew will then board the vessel and so on. The Graphics in the game are of a high standard, as Nvidia is involved (seeing as modern Nvidia games are awesome), so you will need at least a 2.6 GHZ processor and a decent graphics card to withstand the urges ingame. The fighting style in AC4 is incredibly similar to that of AC3, with only a couple of differences. For Â£11 I am incredibly happy, aand will be getting Black Flag soon.",1401895601,1401895601,True,1,0,0.496062248945236206,0,True,False,False,False,,,

9900582,"{'steamid': '76561197997692330', 'num_games_owned': 918, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1396209789}",english,"AMAZING GAME.  It's rather short of course, but the developers have a nice creativity meets willingness to pay margin here in my opinion.  If you don't own AC4 get this now, if you do own it maybe pass because it's more of the same but slighty less of it.. YES it's another AC BUT the pirate theme which is briefly touched upon in 3 is SOOO much cooler here.

Tropical Island paradises ripped right out of history you most likely never knew about.  The game even includes the option to learn all about the people and events in their thesarus thing built into the menu.

The graphics are breathtaking and the story telling is better than ever.  I had to try out AC4 after playing this and my mind was blown.  For the money try this and see if you like the new theme.  It's the new direction they are going and it's interesting.  Keep in mind though AC4 is much more cinematic and much more enveloping as you experience life outside the Anemus and whatnot.

ALSO EVERYBODY HATES UPLAY INCLUDING ME, It's not as bad as others but giving players the option to choose would go a long ways.",1398179340,1398179579,True,2,0,0.513592839241027832,0,True,False,False,False,,,

9591470,"{'steamid': '76561197971485856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1395345843}",english,"If you've beaten Black Flag and want more, this will mostly do the trick. Set 13-15 years after AC4, Adewale has risen from Kenway's right-hand man, to a full-fledged Assassin/Captain. After an intense opening scene, he finds himself washed ashore and caught in the midst of a civil struggle. It's time to free some slaves, hence the subtitle of the game. There are many different scenarios in which you can free said slaves. Some will be locked in a cage, and you have to kill the guard carrying the key. Others will be working on plantations, in which you must eliminate a certain number of guards to free them.

Freeing as many slaves as possible actually grants you bonuses, and sometimes even needed to advance the story. The bonuses range from free restocks on ammunition, to even new weapons. With slaves pratically all over the place ready to be liberated, achieving these bonuses doesn't exactly take a long time.

As you'd expect, Freedom Cry does have naval content, including it's own (DLC sized) open-world map. Attacking and boarding other ships for goods is still relevant, but nowhere near as much as Black Flag. A lot of the locations to discover are unfortunately pretty dull. There's several islands which consist of only a small beach and one chest to open, then you're done there. I'm not sure why Ubisoft even bothered, as it's probably the most disappointing part of FC. Still, just sailing the open sea remains a joy to behold. No sea shanties (pirate songs), however.

Just like Black Flag, Freedom Cry is GORGEOUS. It's a shame that sometimes some information is still present on your screen, even with the HUD options turned ""all off"", because I love taking clean screenshots. Even so, it's such a beautiful game to behold, especially the water. You'll catch yourself just staring at the visuals and remember there's a game to play.

I was surprised with the length of FC. I expected to be done in about 3-4 hours, but my save file clocks-in at almost 9 hours. That's including all side-content. Not a bad chunk of time for a piece of something that's stand-alone DLC. So, if you want a demo of Black Flag, this is the closest you'll get of that experience. Granted, Black Flag is obviously the fuller experience, but I do recommend buying this if you're wondering what it's like.

I am pleased with the time I spent with Freedom Cry. A lovely slice of Assassin/Pirate content to keep one's interest for a decent amount of time.",1395476280,1395476280,True,2,0,0.53057408332824707,0,True,False,False,False,,,

9561090,"{'steamid': '76561198010093355', 'num_games_owned': 903, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1560145261}",english,"This game is for people who want to try out the new Assassin's Creed IV : Blag Flag's gameplay or engine .

9387729,"{'steamid': '76561198084916065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1425808981}",german,"AssassinÂ´s Creed Freedom Cry, der neueste Standalone-DLC des 2013 erschienenen AssassinÂ´s Creed 4 Black Flag, hat mich positiv Ã¼berrascht.

Die Erweiterung handelt von AdÃ©walÃ©, dem als Sklave geborenen und in die Freiheit entflohenen Quartiermeister an Bord der Jackdaw, welches unter Edward Kenways Kommando segelte. 15 Jahre spÃ¤ter ist er bereits von den Assassinen ausgebildet worden und selber KapitÃ¤n seines eigenen Schiffs. Nach einem heftigen Unwetter findet er sich gestrandet in Saint-Dominque wieder, einem von den Franzosen besetzter Teil der Karibik. Dort trifft er auf die Maroon, die ihn Ã¼berreden kÃ¶nnen sie zu unterstÃ¼tzen und die Sklaven zu befreien.

Optisch betrachtet hat Ubisoft mit Freedom Cry zwar keine Meisterleistung vollbracht, aber schÃ¶n anzusehen ist es trotzdem. Auch das HUD ist benutzerfreundlich aufgebaut und leicht zu verstehen. Neben der Stadt Saint-au-Prince kann man in dem Open-World-Adventure mehrere kleine Inseln sowie Plantagen erkunden. Bei seiner Erkundungsreise findet man neue Waffen, Beutel und VerÃ¤nderungen fÃ¼r AdÃ©walÃ©s Schiff, der Experto Crede. Die ganze Karibik zu erforschen wurde uns in dem DLC verwehrt, lediglich der SÃ¼d-Osten des karibischen Meers ist begehbar. StorymÃ¤ÃŸig hÃ¤lt Freedom Cry im Prinzip eine ca. 3-4 stÃ¼ndige Befreihungsaktion von Sklaven bereit, welche allerdings mehr Action bietet als die ersten sieben Sequenzen von Black Flag. Neben der Action sind auch wie in jedem AssassinÂ´s Creed Schleichmissionen vorhanden, welche mich in diesem DLC eher weniger gestÃ¶rt haben als in Black Flag, da sich AdÃ©walÃ© als gebranntmarkter, afrikanischer Immigrant vor SklavenhÃ¤ndlern verdeckt halten muss. Freedom Cry lÃ¤sst sich wie jedes Spiel der Serie einfach spielen und erfordert keinerlei Erfahrung im Umgang mit Controller bzw. mit Maus & Tastatur. Als In-Game Sound hat sich Ubisoft fÃ¼r afrikanische Stammeslieder & viel Percussion-Musik entschieden. Eine gute Entscheidung, da diese hervorragend zum Spiel und der Handlung passen.

Zusammenfassend ist AssassinÂ´s Creed Freedom Cry eine gelungene und spielbare Erweiterung zu Black Flag, die ihr Geld allemal wert ist. Zwar habe ich noch ein paar MÃ¤ngel, wie zb. die verkleinerte Spielwelt oder dass es nur eine Hand voll Freischaltbares gibt, allerdings unterliegen diese Nachteile den Vorteilen des DLCÂ´s.",1394302138,1394818186,True,51,2,0.843684136867523193,0,False,False,False,False,,,

9285497,"{'steamid': '76561197963593718', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1498326827}",english,"This game is  a fun, compelling and interesting addition to the Asssassin's Creed franchise. It borrows the ACIV: Black Flag engine and a character from the game. As with other Assassin's Creed games this one introduces a new character (though Adewale is introduced in ACIV: Black Flag) with a unique Assassins vs. Templars storyline. If you held off on buying ACIV: Black Flag as I did then this game will offer insight into what you are missing. It is the same classic Assassin's Creed formula that makes the series fun with new location, improved visuals and continues the Assassin's fight for a noble cause.
I highly recommend it!",1393547442,1393995479,True,34,0,0.625290155410766602,2,True,False,False,False,,,
